title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at IDinsight in Dec 2020
Interview Descriptions:
The entire process took approximately 3 months - something that was totally preventable and in their control. All-in-all, I think IDinsight staff is extremely insincere, and insensitive about the anxieties that goes through applicants' minds.  

The process begins with a detailed form about yourself, followed by a math test that lasts about an hour. After that, they have two interview rounds. The first interview is more technical - wherein you receive a few case studies that should not be difficult if you know about basic econometrics and RCTs (sampling, stratification, spillovers). They also ask you to solve two basic algebra questions towards the end as well. The second interview is behavioural and so far the weirdest one where they ask you a bunch of questions that I feel should have no bearing on your candidature. It is also clear that they have not changed their interview process in the five-six years of their existence. The questions are quite honestly, annoying, and unsettling. 

The interviewers were quite honestly, disrespectful and rude. There is hardly any need for these kinds of interviews to be stress interviews  (they are on Skype and also, this is not a management position which requires you to test how we respond to stressful situations). The stress interview format does one thing and one thing only: it unsettles and unnerves you, reduces your confidence, makes you nervous. One of the interviewers argued with me over a statistical technique I use at my work nearly everyday - I am not sure whether it was an interview technique to pry into my behaviour, but it reflected badly on them because she was incorrect but almost petulantly insisted that she was correct.  At one point, an interviewer asked me about Stata commands I use (totally a wrong format.. the interview is verbal. If you want to test my coding skills, take a Stata test?) 

The interviewers, I noticed, were also not at all aware about their own recruitment process but wanted to know what questions I have had (both their answers: "good question, but I am not sure"). At one point, one interviewer told me that she was not sure what the entire recruitment process is but she did know how it was three years ago. What should I do with this information and how is it relevant? Shouldn't somebody who is making huge decisions about candidates know what processes they are going through?

IDinsight might think that their processes are standardised but they are not. A colleague of mine who similarly interviewed and ultimately got the offer had a kinder, more professional interviewer. If you aren't asking the same questions from all candidates, how are you hoping to judge how fit they are to the organisation? My conjecture is also that your previous experience and education has a sheepskin effect for IDinsight. You'll be at a significant advantage if you 1) went to a top school 2) worked for organisations that are universally known.

They also ask for references as a part of the recruitment process. References are a form that your referees fill which are again, very weird arbitrary questions that a referee should not reduce their reference to. I also understand that references are a part of an overall 'score' that they ultimately judge you on. References to me, although a significant part of the recruitment, should not be competitive. I have different referees, other candidates have different referees. You cannot compare mine against theirs. It is pointless and unfair. It is also a waste of time if you are not going to recruit most of the people you are asking references from. 

I really regret the time and effort that went into a fruitless recruitment process. Honestly, I would be upset at the lengthy, circuitous process it took had I received the offer. It also is terribly upsetting to know from an insider that there isn't much deliberation in the recruitment process either - just some matching of scores from each round. It should not take three months.
Interview Questions:
First interview is almost entirely technical which I have detailed above.

Second interview is behavioural: here are some of the questions

1. When was the last time you received negative feedback
2. When was the last time you gave feedback to somebody 
3. What was your most adventurous experience

title: Associate Program Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at IDinsight in Jun 2020
Interview Descriptions:
A technical test, followed by 3 interviews and an essay.
Overall the process was pretty difficult with a lot of technical assessment.
However the process was interesting overall. 
Most hiring teams will conduct two to three interviews for an open role. Many roles will include a technical and quantitative interview, an interview to discuss the candidate’s motivation and experience, and a final interview with the applicable regional or functional team lead for a role. Interviews are nearly always conducted virtually due to the international nature of our team. When possible logistically, we may invite candidates to have their final interview in person. If you are invited to a first-round interview for a client-facing role, these resources will help you prepare for the technical case study interview. Interviews usually last between 30 and 60 minutes, and may end early — often some buffer time is scheduled for connectivity and logistical purposes.

Submitted my CV & Cover letter.

2nd Round - Case based interview: Basically how you’d set up and intervention and how you’d carry our impact evaluation. 2 questions at the end like the first quant interview. My interviewer was very lovely and very kind. 

Waited for about 2 weeks to hear back after which you have a timed writing test and another interview.

Writing test - Form an opinion based on an article & argue out your stance. This year’s question was based off an article on the paternalism underlying the SDG slogan “leave no one behind”. 2 hours. 

3rd Round - Interview with Senior managers. They’re basically trying to gauge if you’re a good fit and questions have to do with your experience with development work, why your location preference is what it is, etc. There’s also a bit that goes into your round 2 case with maybe 2 or 3 questions about how you’d evaluate impact if those in the control group moved to treatment group. My interviewer was meh. Like he had better things to do with his time.

(All these are round 3 questions) 

If you had a meeting with Bill Gates what would you ask him?

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at IDinsight in Nov 2017
Interview Descriptions: Campus info session - Online Application (mid October) - Phone Screen w/ Partner (early Nov) - 2nd round Skype w/ Senior Manager (mid Nov)  - Online Timed Writing Assignment (mid Nov)  - Rejection (early Jan) . That hiring process has changed a bit - relative to those detailed earlier. The first interview was originally scheduled to be with a senior manager - but was changed to one of the founding managers several days later. The interview times are still indeed a bit odd (early morning) but it comes with the nature of the work. The interview itself was quite straight forward. Most of the cases described earlier on Glassdoor still applied (textbooks). The interview ended with two quantitative problems: a compound interest and a distance formula problem.  I was free to use whatever resources available (Excel, etc). I didn't leave this interview extremely confident but received the invite back for round 2 within a week and a half. This time, I interviewed with one of the leaders from another division on Skype. This interviewer was a bit more stoic and I could often tell the mood was not as optimistic. The Stata questions and intense skill focus detailed in past reviews is no more. Questions were mostly behavior - one: "Why International Development", was a repeat from before. Still, there were 3 more brain-teaser like algebra problems toward the end of this one as well (salt solution using different sized containers) and a seemingly simple case study on whether a group of farmers should a adopt a new crop recommended by researchers, but that they believe to be unsuited for the climate. The interview wrapped up. I was told I would hear back within 2 weeks. I completed the timed writing assigment (question below) in the alloted hour and a half.  At a strict 400 word limit, much of the last half hour is spent editing. From there, the wait was 47 days, punctuated by several emails that they were carefully making their decisions.
Interview Questions: Please read the article: "The Case for Getting Rid of Borders -- Completely". Agree or disagree and explain why.

title: Associate Interview

Interview Descriptions: There were two rounds of interviews: one case-study and one 'normal' interview. The case-study was questions of how to run a specific impact evaluation project and the normal interview was typical questions about my previous experiences and how they made me suitable for the role.

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at IDinsight in Nov 2017
Interview Descriptions: First round interview consisted of two parts: behavioral and applied. The behavioral was relatively straight-forward, mostly about who you are and why you're interested in the position. The applied portion was essentially a case on how you would set up a RCT (between options given, discuss what is better and why).  I applied for an international position and therefore had a Skype call with the regional office.
Interview Questions: If you are evaluating impact on this project, which of the following methods would you use to measure impact and why?

title: Associate Interview

Interview Questions: Why do you want to join IDInsight and what will you get out of it

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at IDinsight (Mumbai) in Oct 2017
Interview Descriptions:
To begin with, IDinsight is the most unprofessional and opaque organisation I've come across in years of my professional career. There is no hint of transparency in their selection process and show absolutely no regard for a candidate's engagement and career plans. I applied online for the job. After the CV-shortlisting, two rounds of interviews were conducted. First was the technical round which dealt with intricacies of RCT through a case-study. It's necessary that you posses knowledge of econometrics and basic math. The second round was with their India Director. It was a fit interview where they discussed aspects of career interests, goals, personality and team management. Both interviews lasted about an hour.
I cleared both the interview rounds after which they didn't respond for 2 months which was absolutely unexpected from the organization. They retrieved 2 months later to contact my references. A week later, they inform me that they can't make an offer right now. I asked for a feedback to which they blatantly refused. I pushed an employee in the organization to push for the same but they were rude to his requests as well (they'd respond only if they have a reason to reject me). It is not difficult to see what happened behind the doors during these two months of delay . Not discrediting the organisation, but the utter lack of transparency in the selection process coupled with a bias for a certain kind of brand/background completely defeats all arguments for meritocracy. For their lack of professionalism and bias, I'd not recommend anyone apply for this role.
Interview Questions: Imagine you get a chance to interact with Bill Gates. What will you talk to him about?

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at IDinsight (New York, NY) in Apr 2017
Interview Descriptions: Attended information sessions, online application, phone screenings, interviews. This was a terribly long and rigorous process with little reason or explanation. The team was not responsive or considerate of the time-sensitive nature of the post-graduate job-seeking process. It was drawn out and unnecessarily intense. Would've been a cool experience, but the level of feedback and consideration seemed to reflect a lack of coordination, organization, or care for applicant's time and effort. Very disappointed.
Interview Questions: Case interview

title: Associate Interview

Interview Questions: Do you have experience leading a team? and a case interview where you had to go over different types of evaluations

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at IDinsight (New Delhi) in Sept 2016
Interview Descriptions: 3 stage interview, after which they contact your references before making an offer. In the first interview they asked a few basic quantitative questions, and roleplay questions. Though they needed no preparation, they did catch me off guard. The second interview was an hour long technical interview where I was asked about my experience with Stata, and walked through many levels of a scenario that involved both roleplay and quantitative reasoning. I was even asked what Stata commands I would use to test the validity of a relationship given the experimental context and how I would interpret the coefficient, T stat etc. They sent an evaluation methodology table to look over before this interview, though simply studying this would not have been enough for a successful interview. I was flown out to Delhi for my final interview, where I spoke to a partner for about 2 hours. These questions were all to gauge my fit in the organisation, asking questions like what my career plans were in the next 5 yrs and 20 yrs, why I am interested in this type of quantitative analysis, what makes me think I am well prepared for it, how my previous boss would describe me etc.
Interview Questions: Choose one issue that you care deeply about, explain why, take on a personality involved in addressing this issue, tell me 2-3 things you would do fix the problem

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at IDinsight
Interview Descriptions: 3 interviews - 1 strictly technical (evaluation design, mental math, etc.) and 2 more behavioral / fit - related. Interviews are always with at least a couple members of upper management - fit with the organization is very important.
Interview Questions: Typical behavioral questions, asking about previous experiences applied to IDinsight. Some hypothetical scenarios on situations you might face. Lots of self-reflection required.

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at IDinsight (Oxford, England) in Jun 2016
Interview Descriptions: There were three stages of interviews. I got through two and did not make it to the third. The first was described as being a get-to-know-each-other type interview but included quantitative reasoning questions which I was not expecting at all. The interviewer was professional and competent. The second interview walked me through evaluation situations, testing the candidate's knowledge of different evaluation designs and ability to react to different situations. Even though it is an entry-level position, they expect significant field experience which seemed a little unfair to me.
Interview Questions: Quantitative reasoning questions, such as if average income or median income was higher in a country and why?; work done by individuals in a time period if certain amount of work was done by a certain number of individuals etc. Go through quant reasoning questions well!

title: Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at IDinsight (London, England) in Jun 2016
Interview Descriptions: Interview process was very fast. These are people who know what they want from candidates and they go for it. Very rigorous and highly technical questions, even when they inform you that they only want to ask a few questions and you need not prepare for anything. With IDinsight, always be prepared.
Interview Questions: A government intends to increase crop yields of farmers by 20% giving them crop seedlings. To do this, the officials selected 1000 farmers and give the seedlings to 20% of them (n=200). So the government target of increasing yield by 20% has been achieved once crop yields increased amongst the 20% or 200 farmers given the crop seedlings your comment on this?

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at IDinsight
Interview Descriptions: Very rigorous. There are three interviews and each is different than the last. The first interview consists of asking about your relevant work experience. The second interview is a technical interview that tests your knowledge of math and stats. The third interview is with management and asks clarification questions. The second interview is probably the hardest.
Interview Questions: What makes you interested in development?

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at IDinsight (San Francisco, CA) in Mar 2015
Interview Descriptions: 3 rounds of interviews. First round is usually with a manager/senior manager and is a general fit interview assessing your background etc. Second interview is technical and focuses on math as well as evaluation concepts. Third round is conducted with a partner and is again about your fit and why you want to work in the sector
Interview Questions: SAT type math questions in the tech interview

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at IDinsight (Boston, MA) in Dec 2014
Interview Descriptions:
There were three rounds of interviews. The first round interview was initiated within a week of applying to the job. They are very fast at reaching out to you and the interview process is pretty fast. I only made it to the 2nd round but it all happened within a spank of 2 and a half weeks. The first round was around 30 minutes long. It was definitely not easy but not as difficult as the second round. 

The second round was 80 minutes long and very in-depth! You need to be familiar with quasi-experimental methodologies. They ask you about your background with impact evaluations and research background. Afterwards, they provide you with hypothetical scenarios and you have to answer based on your knowledge about impact evaluation and quasi-experimental methodologies. They keep going deeper into the questions and providing additional questions to the first question. They then ask you math/logic questions. They ask you about your experience with STATA and a couple STATA related questions. 

The second round interview was very intimidating and hard. Definitely prepare and study in advance! Good Luck!
Interview Questions:
First Round - (Answer if true or false) The median income in the US is greater than the mean income. 

Second Round - The Ministry of Education is providing underperforming schools with textbooks. The Minister says there is a 15% increase in the test scores of these schools after the textbooks were provided. The Minister wants to know if this is a significant value and if he should scale up?

title: Full Time Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at IDinsight in Nov 2014
Interview Descriptions: 3 round interview process. First and second via skype (no video). First round pretty basic, with behavioral questions, for the second round, they give you a prep sheet based on which they ask more case style questions (you're supposed to use the concepts on the prep sheet to answer). The interviewers are all graduates from top schools, generally interviewing from one of the field locations, so the interview takes place at weird times.
Interview Questions: The first round had a couple of mental math questions that I wasn't expecting. Basic statistics (distribution) and math-- keep a pencil around.
